faulty generalization.definition: an informal fallacy wherein a conclusion is drawn about all or many instances of a phenomenon on the basis of one or a few instances of that phenomenon. is an example of jumping to conclusions.
faulty generalization.example1: Flight attendants are the nicest people. I should know—I’ve taken two flights.
faulty generalization.example2: The two courses I took at UWI were not very interesting. I don't think its a good university.

exampleArg1support.faulty generalization fallacy support: I know four poor families. They are lazy drug addicts. Therefore, all poor people are lazy drug addicts.

exampleArg2support.faulty generalization fallacy support: Investing in renewable technologies is wise because all such investments lead to success.

exampleArg1counter.faulty generalization fallacy counter: I met a successful person from poverty. Therefore, all people in poverty can easily overcome be successful without systemic barriers

exampleArg2counter.faulty generalization fallacy counter: I invested once in renewables, and it didn't yield profits. Therefore, investing in all renewable technologies is financially unwise and unprofitable

false causality.definition: statement that jumps to a conclusion implying a causal relationship without supporting evidence
false causality.example1: The bigger a child's shoe size, the better the child's handwriting
false causality.example2: I failed Pre-Cal because my teacher doesn’t like me.

exampleArg1support.topic: The importance of mathematics in schools
exampleArg1support.false causality fallacy support: If Mathematics is made compulsory, then it will lead to guaranteed success in unrelated future endeavors.

exampleArg2support.false causality fallacy support: If you invest in renewable technologies, then it will guarantee automatic financial gains without concrete evidence or direct causation.

exampleArg1counter.topic: The importance of mathematics in schools
exampleArg1counter.false causality fallacy counter: Eliminating mathematics from school boosts creativity in students.

exampleArg2counter.false causality fallacy counter: If you invest in renewable technologies, you might lose all your money because they are not advanced

circular reasoning.definition: when the end of an argument comes back to the beginning without having proven itself.
circular reasoning.example1: Mr. Casal was very tired because he had no energy.
circular reasoning.example2: The news is fake because so much of the news is fake.

exampleArg1support.topic: People should not be forced to exercise their right to vote.
exampleArg1support.circular reasoning fallacy support: Forcing people to vote is wrong because it's not right to make them do something they shouldn't be forced to do.

exampleArg2support.circular reasoning fallacy support: The universe has a beginning. Every thing that has a beginning has a cause. Therefore, the universe has a cause called God.

exampleArg1counter.topic: People should not be forced to exercise their right to vote.
exampleArg1counter.circular reasoning fallacy counter: Forcing people to vote is right because it forces them to participate in politics

ad populum.definition: a fallacious argument which is based on affirming that something is real or better because the majority thinks so
ad populum.example1: Everyone is wearing the new skinny jeans from American Eagle. Are you?
ad populum.example2: An increasing number of people are keeping ferrets as pets, so they must make wonderful companion animals.

exampleArg1support.topic: People should not be forced to exercise their right to vote.
exampleArg1support.ad populum fallacy support: Most people believe that forcing citizens to vote goes against their rights. Therefore, it's wrong to compel individuals to vote.

exampleArg2support.ad populum fallacy support: Investing in renewable technologies is the popular choice, so it must be the best financial option.

exampleArg3.topic: Should Mathematics be a Compulsory Course
exampleArg3.ad populum fallacy support: Everyone thinks Mathematics should be compulsory, it must be the right decision.

exampleArg4.ad populum fallacy support: Everyone who is really into gaming already owns the latest video game. Don't be the only one left out!

ad hominem.definition: instead of addressing someone's argument or position, you irrelevantly attack the person or some aspect of the person who is making the argument.
ad hominem.example1: She is a teacher in a public school, so any claims that she makes about the public school system are biased and untrue.
ad hominem.example2: Vote for me because the other candidate is a cheat and a liar!

exampleArg1support.topic: Mathematics should be a Compulsory Course
exampleArg1support.ad hominem fallacy support: Those who oppose Mathematics as compulsory lack intelligence and are against progress.

exampleArg2support.ad hominem fallacy support: Critics of investing in renewable technologies are simply ignorant about modern financial strategies.

exampleArg3.topic: Should Mathematics be a Compulsory Course
exampleArg3.ad hominem fallacy support: Those who oppose Mathematics as compulsory lack intelligence and are against progress.

fallacy of logic.definition: an error in the logical structure of an argument.
fallacy of logic.example1: Not tipping your waiter is like stealing money right out of someone's wallet.
fallacy of logic.example2: Most heroin users started out smoking pot. If you start smoking pot, you’ll end up a heroin user, too.

exampleArg1support.fallacy of logic fallacy support: All elderly people who retire at a certain age become less productive. Therefore, making retirement optional will instantly make them more productive.

exampleArg2support.fallacy of logic fallacy support: God must exist because the Bible says so, and the Bible is the word of God.

exampleArg3.fallacy of logic fallacy support: Fast food is unhealthy because it's bad for your health.

exampleArg4.fallacy of logic fallacy support: God must exist because the Bible says so, and the Bible is the word of God.

appeal to emotion.definition: manipulation of the recipient's emotions in order to win an argument
appeal to emotion.example1: You have to give me a passing grade. I spent 150 hours on that project and missed every party this quarter.
appeal to emotion.example2: Salesguy: You should definitely buy this car.  You look so good in it -- you look at least ten years younger behind that wheel.Tamera: I’ll take it!

exampleArg1support.appeal to emotion fallacy support: We must stop animal experiments because just the thought of those innocent animals suffering is heartbreaking.

exampleArg2support.appeal to emotion fallacy support: We should support environmental conservation because the future of our children depends on a clean and sustainable environment.

false dilemma.definition: presenting only two options or sides when there are many options or sides.
false dilemma.example1: Either go to the party or spend the night in your room crying.
false dilemma.example2: You could either pursue your dream job or stay where you are and be miserable for the rest of your life.

exampleArg1support.topic: Social media allows people to connect with people that they otherwise could not connect with
exampleArg1support.false dilemma fallacy support: You can either use social media to connect with people you wouldn't otherwise, or you can remain isolated and disconnected from the world.

exampleArg2support.topic: Replacing fossil fuels with renewable energy
exampleArg2support.false dilemma fallacy support: We should switch to renewable energy or the world will collapse

exampleArg3.topic: The importance of mathematics in schools
exampleArg3.false dilemma fallacy support: Study math or have no critical thinking

equivocation.definition: when a key term or phrase in an argument is used in an ambiguous way, with one meaning in one portion of the argument and then another meaning in another portion of the argument.
equivocation.example1: The officer told me to freeze but it was too hot out to be freezing, so I was justified in running away.
equivocation.example2: Science shows us that improved quality of life comes through research and invention.

exampleArg1support.equivocation fallacy support: Television is valuable because it holds significant monetary value in the entertainment industry.

exampleArg2support.equivocation fallacy support: does the term 'tighten' mean 'enhance security' or 'restrict freedom', it is confusing.

exampleArg3.equivocation fallacy support: 'Expanding' voting rights blurs 'universal access' and 'changing eligibility', confusing discussions.

fallacy of extension.definition: attacking an exaggerated or caricatured version of your opponent's position.
fallacy of extension.example1: Person 1: I think pollution is the cause of climate change. Person 2: So you think humans cause hurricanes and tsunamis?
fallacy of extension.example2: Coronavirus originated in China, therefore all Chinese people are sick.

exampleArg1support.fallacy of extension support: Painting restrictions as total ban misrepresents responsible, humane testing practices in scientific research.

exampleArg2support.fallacy of extension support: Portraying change as erasing core subjects distorts the need for evolving, inclusive educational content.

fallacy of relevance.definition: introducing premises or conclusions that have nothing to do with the subject matter.
fallacy of relevance.exampfle1: Violent video games are directly related to gun violence in schools and should be banned for teens. The school day should start an hour later.
fallacy of relevance.example2: Why should we be worrying about how the government treats Native people, when people in our city can't get a job?

exampleArg1support.topic: The importance of mathematics in schools
exampleArg1support.fallacy of relevance fallacy support: Mathematics should be mandatory. it builds character, like tasting exotic foods, enriching life experiences.

exampleArg2support.fallacy of relevance fallacy support: The existence of God is as crucial as colorful paint in art. Belief fuels innovation, like mixing colors for a masterpiece.

fallacy of credibility.definition: attempts to disprove an argument by attacking the character of the speaker.
fallacy of credibility.example1: Beyond Meat burgers are healthy for us because they do not have any meat in them.
fallacy of credibility.example2: I saw Ashton Kutcher in a commercial for male skin care. He's looking good for his age, so I'm willing to try the product. He must know what he's talking about.

exampleArg1support.fallacy of credibility fallacy support: We should abolish the death penalty. Many respected people, such as actor Guy Handsome, have publicly stated their opposition to it.

exampleArg2support.fallacy of credibility fallacy support: I admire the president for being a good role model. REPLY: But the New York Times says he's a lousy role model, so you're wrong.

intentional.definition: some intentional (sometimes subconscious) action/choice to incorrectly support an argument
intentional.example1: Yes, I do think that all drunk drivers should go to prison, but your honor, he is my son! He is a good boy who just made a mistake!
intentional.example2: Bill: I think that some people have psychic powers.  Jill: What is your proof? Bill: No one has been able to prove that people do not have psychic powers.

exampleArg1support.intentional fallacy support: You can't prove that aliens don't exist, so they must be real

exampleArg2support.intentional fallacy support: How many school shootings should we tolerate before we change the gun laws?
